awd_titl_txt: CRII: CPS: Modeling Subsurface Features and Connected Autonomous Vehicles as Cyber-Physical Systems for Reciprocal Mapping and Localization
awd_abstract_narration:
Underneath the ground of modern cities exists a labyrinth of subsurface infrastructure consisting of water pipes, utility cables, and gas lines. This project proposes to study the use of sensor-equipped autonomous vehicles to accurately map this complicated network and explore how to leverage the subsurface infrastructure as invariant landmarks to provide reliable and secure vehicle navigation. If successful, this research will result in automated tools that make better maps of urban subsurface to improve buried infrastructure and prevent accidents when digging is required; as well as create a new means to navigate autonomous vehicle in cluttered and distressed urban areas during and after natural or man-made disasters. This project will also offer career development opportunities for participating students including those from underrepresented groups.

To achieve these objectives, multiple connected and autonomous vehicles will be equipped with ground penetrating radar to collect radargrams of subsurface infrastructure along coordinated trajectories. A novel algorithm will be created to detect and identify the signatures in radargram that correspond to elements of the subsurface infrastructure. The unwanted features such as signal interferences and signature occlusions will be turned into useful clues to aggregate multiple radargrams to produce complete subsurface maps. From these maps, a new radargram-based odometry method will be devised to estimate the global poses of connected vehicles based on partially observed vehicle-feature networks. The methods will be tested and evaluated to determine how key parameters such as vehicle speed and network topology affect the accuracy of mapping, localization, and navigation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The lack of complete and accurate maps of city subsurface and buried infrastructure systems prevents timely infrastructure maintenance and rehabilitation, causes utility strikes, and poses threats to public safety. To address this challenge, this project aimed to develop a cyber-physical system integrating ground penetrating radar sensing, vehicle localization and mapping technique, and machine learning based data processing approach for producing more complete and accurate city subsurface maps. First, novel methods based on deep learning were developed to process ground penetrating radar scans of the subsurface to detect, locate, and characterize subsurface objects and assess conditions of infrastructure systems. Second, a new method was developed to integrate simultaneous localization and mapping with surface scene understanding to link and register the produced subsurface maps. Third, the applicability of the developed cyber-physical system was tested in various applications including city subsurface mapping, infrastructure assessment, disaster response, and vehicle localization and navigation.

 

This project also generated broader impacts. First, the application of the developed cyber-physical system and tools will potentially improve the mapping practice of city subsurface and infrastructure systems in the U.S., thereby facilitating infrastructure upgrading and maintenance and preventing incidents such as utility strikes and sinkhole disasters. Given the ambitious plan of the U.S. to revamp its infrastructure systems and build resilience, this project will produce enormous societal and economic benefits. Second, this project supported multiple undergraduate and graduate students, including those from underrepresented groups, to receive rigorous scientific and engineering education and training, preparing them with technical expertise and experience to excel in their chosen careers. The results from this project were incorporated into undergraduate and graduate curricula to enhance STEM workforce development and training. Third, this project invited K-12 students and the public to experience interactive and novel technologies, stimulating their interests in STEM and improving their awareness of new technology development, research, and application. Fourth, the tools developed were also made available to stakeholders and agencies such as the Tennessee Department of Transportation for potential applications.

 


Last Modified: 07/30/2022
Modified by: Shuai Li
